revision.comment: [[Category:Military units and formations of the British Empire in World War II]]
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=I Airborne Corps |image= |caption= |dates=1943–1945 |country={{flag|United Kingdom}} |allegiance= |branch={{army|United Kingdom}} |type=[[Infantry]] |role=[[Airborne forces]] |size=[[Corps]] |command_structure=[[First Allied Airborne Army]] |garrison= |current_commander= |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |notable_commanders=[[Frederick Browning|Frederick Arthur Montague Browning]]
[[Richard Gale (British Army officer)|Richard Nelson Gale]] |identification_symbol=[[File:British Airborne Units.svg|200px]] |identification_symbol_1=British airborne forces emblem |nickname=''Red Devils'' {{#tag:ref|The [[1st Parachute Brigade (United Kingdom)|1st Parachute Brigade]] had been called the "Rote Teufel" or "Red Devils" by the German troops they had fought in [[North African Campaign|North Africa]]. The title was officially confirmed by [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] [[Harold Alexander, 1st Earl Alexander of Tunis|Sir Harold Alexander]] and henceforth applied to all British airborne troops.Otway, p.88|group=nb}} |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles= |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= }} The '''I Airborne Corps''' was an [[airborne forces]] [[corps]] raised by the [[British Army during the Second World War]]. Together with the [[XVIII Airborne Corps|U.S. XVIII Airborne Corps]] it was part of the [[First Allied Airborne Army]]. ==Formation== Under the command of [[Lieutenant-general (United Kingdom)|Lieutenant-General]] [[Frederick Browning|Frederick Arthur Montague Browning]], ''I Airborne Corps'' was formed in 1943, with the [[1st Airborne Division (United Kingdom)|1st]] and [[6th Airborne Division (United Kingdom)|6th Airborne Division]]s under command.Horn and Wyczynski, p.294 In August 1944, the corps became part of the [[First Allied Airborne Army]], alongside [[XVIII Airborne Corps|U.S. XVIII Airborne Corps]]. Later in the war, as well as the 1st and 6th Airborne Divisions, the corps had the [[1st SAS Brigade|1st Special Air Service Brigade]], the [[1st Independent Parachute Brigade (Poland)|Polish 1st Parachute Brigade]] and the [[52nd (Lowland) Infantry Division]] an air-transportable division under corps command.Otway, p.202Otway, p.210 Other units assigned to the corps were the American [[82nd Airborne Division|82nd]], and [[101st Airborne Division]]s during [[Operation Market Garden]] in September 1944. Lieutenant-General [[Richard Gale (British Army officer)|Richard Nelson Gale]], who had previously commanded the 6th Airborne Division during the [[Operation Overlord|Battle of Normandy]], took command of the corps in December 1944.[http://www.pegasusarchive.org/normandy/richard_gale.htm Richard Gale] Pegassus archive ==Notes== ;Footnotes {{reflist|group=nb}} ;Citations {{reflist}} ==References== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|last1=Horn|last2=Wyczynski|first1=Bernd|first2=Michel|title=Paras versus the Reich: Canada's paratroopers at war, 1942-45|publisher=Dundurn Press Ltd|year=2003|isbn=978-1-55002-470-8}} *{{cite book| last=Otway| first=Lieutenant-Colonel T.B.H| title=The Second World War 1939–1945 Army – Airborne Forces| publisher=Imperial War Museum|location=London|year= 1990| isbn=0-901627-57-7}} {{refend}} {{British parachute units of the Second World War}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1 Airborne}} [[Category:British field corps|Airborne]] [[Category:Corps of the British Army in World War II|Airborne]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1943]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 1945]] [[Category:Airborne units and formations of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1943 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1945 disestablishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Military units and formations of the British Empire in World War II]]
